{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} '''Rita Marie Lavelle''' (born 1946) is a [[United States]] and [[California|California State]] [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] political figure. In 1984, Lavelle was convicted on federal charges of [[perjury]] related to an investigation into misuse of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]'s "[[Superfund]]" money during her tenure with the agency, and irregularities at the [[Stringfellow Acid Pits]], a major hazardous waste site. The Lavelle incident was labeled "Sewergate" or "Garbagegate" by the newspapers at the time.<ref>[http://www.nndb.com/people/524/000026446/ Michael Deaver]. nndb.com</ref>
In 2004, Lavelle was convicted again on unrelated federal charges of one count of [[wire fraud]] and two counts of [[making false statements]] to the F.B.I. Lavelle committed these crimes in her NuTECH Enterprises, Inc. business of environmental consultation.
==Biography== In 1969, Lavelle earned her bachelor's degree in Biology and Mathematics, with a minor in chemistry, from [[Holy Names University]] in [[Oakland, California]]. She continued her graduate work at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in physiological chemistry and stoichiometry. She earned a master's degree cum laude in business administration from [[Pepperdine University]] in 1980.
From 1969 to 1976, she was the [[California State Consumer Affairs Department]] information officer, state director of consumer education, and publications assistant in the office of then-Governor [[Ronald Reagan]]. She was director of marketing for Intercontinental and Continental Chemical Corporation in Sacramento, California, from 1976 to 1978. Lavelle's responsibilities included development of corporate guidelines to comply with the [[Resource Conservation and Recovery Act]], a law that her later position at the EPA left her to administer nationwide compliance with by both business and government sectors. {{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
Beginning in 1978, Lavelle initiated, directed and managed several programs for [[Aerojet-General Corporation]] subsidiaries; these included programs for divisions which manufactured chemicals and industrial and chemical intermediates, nuclear and chemical waste treatment systems, [[liquid rocket engines]] for the aerospace industry, and high-speed marine propulsion systems for defence applications.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
When Lavelle joined Aerojet-General Corporation, she became director of communications for one subsidiary, Cordova Chemical Co., until 1979, moving to a similar communications position for the largest subsidiary, Aerojet Liquid Rocket Co., in 1979.
In 1981, she was named one of the outstanding women in aerospace by ''Aerospace Magazine''.
On February 18, 1982, President [[Ronald Reagan]] announced his intention to nominate Lavelle for assistant administrator of the [[United States|U.S.]] [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] for solid waste and emergency response. Her position included directing the hazardous waste control program and the $1.6 billion "[[Superfund]]" program which provides for the emergency cleanup of chemical spills and hazardous waste dumps.
EPA Administrator [[Anne Gorsuch]] described Lavelle as bringing "over 12 years of professional experience in state government and private industry to the agency", and went on to say that "she has demonstrated expertise in getting results, as shown by her record with the executive branch of government in California, with a mid-sized chemical firm and with a large diversified international corporation."<ref>{{cite press release|title=Rita M. Lavelle |publisher=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] |date=February 18, 1982 |url=http://www.epa.gov/history/admin/oswer/lavelle.htm |accessdate=June 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618104612/http://www.epa.gov/history/admin/oswer/lavelle.htm |archivedate=June 18, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref>
Lavelle had held several positions of responsibility in the California [[Republican Party of the United States|Republican Party]], including membership on the executive board of directors of California Federated Republican Women and the [[Sacramento County, California|Sacramento]] and [[Alameda County, California|Alameda County]] central committees.
==Superfund scandal== Lavelle was indicted on federal perjury charges after an investigation was launched based on evidence submitted by another EPA employee, [[whistleblower]] [[Hugh Kaufman]]. The evidence showed that Lavelle was involved with misuse of the EPA's "Superfund" money<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sierraclub.org/sierra/green-life/neil-gorsuch-s-family-has-checkered-history-when-it-comes-environmental-protection|title=Neil Gorsuch’s Family Has a Checkered History When It Comes to Environmental Protection|author=David Helvarg |date=February 1, 2017|website=sierraclub.org}}</ref> during her tenure with the agency, and irregularities at the Stringfellow Acid Pits, a major hazardous waste site. In 1984, Lavelle was convicted of lying to the Congress and served three months of a six-month prison sentence, paid a $10,000 fine and was under probation for five years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shabecoff|first=Philip|date=January 10, 1984|title=Rita Lavelle gets 6-month term and is fined $10,000 for perjury|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|volume=|issue=|page=A1|id=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/us/rita-lavelle-gets-6-month-term-and-is-fined-10000-for-perjury.html|accessdate=June 17, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|date=May 25, 1987|title=Morality Among the Supply-Siders|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|volume=|issue=|page=3|id=|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,964451,00.html|accessdate= June 17, 2009}}</ref>
==Environmental conviction== Lavelle and a partner owned NuTECH Enterprises, Inc., an [[environmental consulting]] firm in [[Oceanside, California]]. Lavelle and Robert V. Cole, a part owner of [[Denova Environmental, Inc.]], a [[hazardous waste]] storage facility in [[Rialto, California]], forged documents that purportedly bore the signature of Joseph Bertelli, the owner of Lemco Corporation in [[South Los Angeles]], to make it appear that Bertelli owed Cole's company more than $52,000 for the removal and storage of hazardous waste. Those documents were used to obtain $36,441 from Capital Partners USA, Inc. Only when Capital Partners attempted to collect from Bertelli did it realize that Bertelli had neither signed the documents nor agreed to the bill, and Denova had never removed hazardous waste for Lemco. {{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
On September 24, 2004, a jury in [[Los Angeles]] federal court found Lavelle guilty of one count of [[wire fraud]] and two counts of [[making false statements]] to the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI). Cole pleaded guilty to one count of wire fraud and was sentenced on December 16, 2004, to one year of probation and was ordered to pay a $3,000 fine. Lavelle was sentenced on January 10, 2005 to 15 months in federal prison.<ref>{{cite press release|title= Former E.P.A. official sentenced to federal prison for defrauding owner of Los Angeles HazMat site|publisher=United States Attorney's Office, Central District of California|date=January 10, 2005|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/cac/pressroom/pr2005/002.html|accessdate= November 18, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115172148/http://www.justice.gov/usao/cac/Pressroom/pr2005/002.html|archivedate=January 15, 2012}}</ref> Rita Lavelle, [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] # 29753-112, was released on July 6, 2007.<ref>"[http://www.bop.gov/inmateloc/ Inmate Locator]." [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]]. Retrieved on June 6, 2015.</ref>

'''Secular liberalism''' is the separation of [[culture]] and [[politics]] from [[religion]]. A subcategory of [[liberalism]] and [[secularism]], it supports the [[separation of religion and state]] particularly from the ideas of the [[Christian Church]]. Christian ideals are usually to be found on the opposite end of the spectrum from secular liberalism. Secular liberalism is often connected with standing for [[social equality]] and [[political freedom|freedom]].<ref name="realclearpolitics">{{cite web |url = http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2009/04/secular_liberalism_as_consensu.html |title = ''Secular Liberalism as Consensus'' |author=Rod Dreher |date=6 April 2011 |publisher = Real Clear Politics |accessdate = 9 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="abc">{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/unleashed/40148.html | title = ''Secular liberalism misunderstood''| publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | date = | accessdate = 2011-06-09}}</ref>
== Beliefs == Adherents of secular liberalism believe in the [[disestablishment]] of the Christian Church.<ref name="guardian">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2010/apr/29/clegg-disestablishment-church-england | title = ''Clegg should assert secular liberalism''| publisher = The Guardian | date = 29 April 2010| accessdate = 2011-06-09 | location=London | first=Theo | last=Hobson}}</ref> Secular liberalism also depends on the conviction that religious tradition and belief has no binding authority on society.<ref name="realclearpolitics"/> Public promoters of secular liberalism, such as Dawkins call for a clear distinction between the teaching of religion as a historical and cultural phenomenon and the teaching of religion as fact. Dawkins has likened using education to indoctrinate children with a particular religion to [[child abuse]]. One of the central tenets of the ideology is separation of church and state.<ref name="abc"/><ref name="guardian"/> Among those who follow secular liberalism are [[Richard Dawkins]], [[Christopher Hitchens]], [[Ayaan Hirshi Ali]] and [[Sam Harris (author)|Sam Harris]].<ref name="abc"/>
Practices that are considered to be illiberal are reformed in a state that practices secular liberalism.<ref name="jstor">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2010/apr/29/clegg-disestablishment-church-england | title = Secular Liberalism and Moral Psychology of Identity''| publisher = Economic and Political Weekly| date = 1997-10-04| accessdate = 2012-02-21| location=London| first=Theo| last=Hobson}}</ref> Legal measures have failed in the past because no effort is made to make a concept of the goods that the community has cherished in the past.<ref name="jstor"/> This lack of reason-giving apparatus is called [[communitarianism]] and it used to criticize the liberal state as a coercive organization.<ref name="jstor"/> Communitarianism essentially advocates a sense of intra-community (community-wide) democracy.<ref name="jstor"/>
In a modern democratic society, a plurality of conflicting doctrines share an uneasy co-existence within the framework of civilization.
== Contemporary application == === Arab Spring === Secular liberalism is sometimes connected with the [[Arab Spring]] protests. One commentator labels it as a "secular liberal fantasy".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/dec/09/tahrir-square-aflame-imaginary-revolution |title=Tahrir Square aflame: the visual basis of an imaginary revolution |author=Jonathan Jones |date=9 December 2011 |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=14 February 2012 |location=London}}</ref> Others have labeled the motivations behind it, and the temporary governments created as a result as secular liberalism. <ref>{{cite book |title= After the Arab Spring: How Islamists Hijacked the Middle East Revolts|last=Bradley |first=John |year= 2012|publisher= |location= |isbn= 0-230-33819-4|page= |pages= |url= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Why Islamism is Winning |author=John M. Owen IV |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/07/opinion/why-islamism-is-winning.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=6 January 2012 |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Khan |first1=Razib |year= 2012|title= Secular liberals the tip of the Islamist spear|journal= Discover Magazine|volume= |issue= |pages= |publisher= |doi= |url= http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/gnxp/2012/01/secular-liberals-the-tip-of-the-islamist-spear/|accessdate=14 January 2012}} </ref>
Oftentimes, participation in the newly crowned democratic governments by the Muslim clerics are ignored in favor of the protesters' secular liberal ideas. Since 2011, more residents of the Middle East have been demanding a greater say in the running of their governments. They want democracy to appear in a uniquely Muslim fashion rather than through some artificial "secular" movement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://goingtotehran.com/2014/02 |title=America and the Middle East: It’s Déjà Vu All Over Again |author=Flynt Leverett and Hillary Mann Leverett |date=11 February 2014 |accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref>
=== France === The [[French ban on face covering]] has been attributed by some to be a result of secular liberalism.<ref name="hizb">{{cite web | url = http://www.hizb.org.uk/current-affairs/french-face-veil-ban-highlights-the-failings-of-secular-liberalism | title = French Face Veil Ban Highlights The Failings Of Secular Liberalism| publisher = Hizb ut-Tahrir | date = 14 September 2010| accessdate = 13 February 2012}}</ref> The ban by the [[French Senate]] on September 14, 2010 outlawed coverings, including religious ones such as the [[burqa]]. Some [[Islam in France|French Muslims]] have found secular liberalism to be an ideology where prejudice against a minority group is used to win [[vote]]s.<ref name="hizb"/> According to the [[Hizb ut-Tahrir]] group, based out of the United Kingdom, women are secluded from society and made [[outcast (person)|outcast]]s in society for trying to be [[Modesty|modest]].<ref name="hizb"/> The group has also criticized other European countries for similar bans on religious dress.
== Criticism == The [[Holy See|Vatican]] and the [[Russian Orthodox Church|Moscow Patriarchate]] are waging a common fight against secular liberalism; claiming that this idea violates the traditional Christian concepts of family and human values by exposing people to medico-biological experiments that are incompatible with their ideas of human dignity.<ref name="interfax">{{cite web | url = http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=7927 | title = ''Moscow Patriarchate, Vatican wage common fight against secular liberalism - Patriarch Kirill''| publisher = Interfax-Religion | date = | accessdate = 2011-06-09}}</ref> The [[Primate (bishop)|Primate]] of the Russian Orthodox Church expressed concern over trends in some [[Protestantism|Protestant]] communities towards liberalizing theology and Christian morals; he claims them to be products of secular liberalism.<ref name="interfax"/>
The [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] of the [[United States Constitution]], offering [[freedom of speech]], has been criticized in a 2004 political manifesto by [[David Fergusson (theologian)|David Fergusson]] entitled ''Church, state and civil society''.

page.title: Taxation of the Jews in Europe

revision.text:
'''Taxation of the Jews in Europe''' refers to taxes imposed specifically on [[Jewish]] people in [[Europe]], in addition to the taxes levied on the general population. Special taxation imposed on the Jews by the state or ruler of the territory in which they were living has played an important part in Jewish history.<ref name="Judaica">[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/ancienttaxation.html Taxation. Encyclopaedia Judaica.] Reproduced by Jewish Virtual Library.</ref> The abolition of special taxes on the Jews followed their admission to civil rights in France and elsewhere in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries.<ref name="Judaica"/>
== In the Roman Empire == The [[Fiscus Judaicus]] ([[Latin]]: "Jewish tax") or "Temple Tax" was a [[tax]] collecting agency instituted to collect the tax imposed on [[Jewish diaspora#Post-Roman Diaspora|Jews]] in the [[Roman Empire]] after the destruction of the [[Second Temple|Temple of Jerusalem]] in 70 CE in favor of the temple of [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus|Jupiter Capitolinus]] in [[Ancient Rome|Rome]].
The tax was initially imposed by [[Roman Emperor]] [[Vespasian]] as one of the [[Anti-Judaism|measures against Jews]] as a result of the [[First Roman-Jewish War]] of 66–73 CE. Vespasian imposed the tax in the aftermath of the [[First Jewish–Roman War|Jewish revolt]] (Josephus ''BJ'' 7. 218; Dio Cassius 65.7.2). The tax was imposed on all Jews throughout the empire, not just on those who took part in the revolt against Rome. The tax was imposed after the [[destruction of the Second Temple]] in 70 CE in place of the levy (or [[Tithe]]) payable by Jews towards the upkeep of the Temple. The amount levied was two [[denarius|denarii]], equivalent to the one-half of a [[shekel]] that observant Jews had previously paid for the upkeep of the Temple of Jerusalem ({{bibleverse||Exodus|30:13|HE}}). The tax was to go instead to the [[Temple of Capitoline Jupiter]], the major center of [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]]. The ''fiscus Iudaicus'' was a humiliation for the Jews.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} In Rome, a special [[procurator (Roman)|procurator]] known as ''procurator ad capitularia Iudaeorum'' was responsible for the collection of the tax.<ref name="Fiscus">"Fiscus Judaicus", ''Encyclopedia Judaica''</ref> Only those who had abandoned Judaism were exempt from paying it.
== In the Holy Roman Empire == The Jewish populations of Europe were politically insecure and could be easily exploited for the levying of heavy taxes in exchange for official protection. The high interest rates charged by Jews became an illimitable source of tax revenue and Jewish wealth was technically easy to gauge because Jews typically stored their assets in the form of cash or promissory notes.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
The Imperial Tax Register of 1241 was the first register to include taxes on the Jews. The total of the taxes on the Jews listed in the Register amounted to 857 silver marks; the total contribution of all the cities together amounted to 4.290 silver marks. These local taxes served wholly or in part to finance town-building. Not all of the contributions reached the central administration. In contrast, it is clear from the Register that the payments made by the Jews reached the Exchequer in their entirety.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 13–14</ref> The taxes on the Jews were first described as the ’’Jewish Tax’’ in 1330.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 18–19</ref>
The Opferfennig (originally Guldenpfennig) tax was introduced in 1342 by Emperor [[Louis IV the Bavarian]], who ordered all Jews above the age of 12 and possessing 20 gulden to pay one gulden annually for protection. This taxation was 1 florin for every Jew and included assets worth more than 20 florins. Widows were not exempted. King Wenceslas removed the taxable minimum but an exemption for Jews dependent on alms was made later by Sigsmund, who himself levied heavy taxation. Sigsmund taxed a third of the value of Jewish properties. It was represented as a coronation tax as part of Sigsmund's attempts to ascend the throne. Isenmann disagrees and believes it was an innovation sprouted by Archchamberlain Konrad von Weinsberg. By 1433-4 the tax collectors were collecting tax worth a half of Jewish properties.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
Emperor [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]] later ordered the income of the Opferfennig tax to be delivered to the archbishop of [[Triers]]. This tax was at some places replaced by an overall communal tax.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0015_0_15120.html OPFERPFENNIG. Encyclopaedia Judaica]. 2008.</ref>
== Leibzoll ==
The ''[[Leibzoll]]'' or ''Judengeleit'' was a special [[tariff|toll]] which Jews had to pay in most of the European states in the [[Middle Ages]] and up to the beginning of the nineteenth century.<ref>{{Cite book| author=Isidore Singer, Cyrus Adler | title=The Jewish Encyclopedia, Vol. 7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SzsyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA669| year=1906| publisher=Funk & Wagnalls Company|page=669}}</ref>
== In Hungary == [[Tolerance tax]] (Toleranzgebührer) was a [[tax]] that was levied against [[Jews]] of [[Hungary]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]], beginning in 1747.<ref name="jg">JewishGen. Hungary: Assorted Census Records, 1781-1850 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: The Generations Network, Inc., 2008.</ref>
The tax was based on the German statute that a Jew was obliged to pay a certain tax to be "tolerated".<ref>Wine and thorns in Tokay Valley: Jewish life in Hungary : the history of Abaújszántó, by Zahava Szász Stessel, Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1995, p. 50-51</ref>
== In Poland ==
=== Koło === In 1571 a contract was drafted with regard to the status of the Jews in [[Koło]], in which the city's Christians have undertaken to provide protection to the Jews, in return for which the Jews were required to pay a special annual municipal tax.<ref name="mahler">Mahler, Rafael. [http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/kolo/kol008.html "From the near and far past". Some information about the history of the Jews of Koło.]</ref>
In 1729 the Jewish community was required to pay 150 gold coins as an annual poll tax, and in 1738 this sum was increased to 300 gold coins.<ref name="mahler"/>
In 1775 the Polish parliament imposed a special duty on books written in [[Hebrew]] and [[Yiddish]], requiring each book to be stamped by the municipality. Despite heavy penalties imposed on owners of unstamped books, many books were concealed and unstamped.<ref name="mahler"/>
== In Russia == The Russian [[Kosher tax]], known as the ''korobka'', was a tax paid only by Jews for each animal slaughtered in accordance with the [[kashrut]] rules and for each pound of this meat sold.<ref name="ji"/><ref>[http://www.shtetlinks.jewishgen.org/kraziai/history_tax_on_jews.htm Korobka Tax on Kraziai's Jews], Document 49-1-1362 from the Kaunas Archive</ref> It was part of the Russian Jewish "basket tax" or "box tax". Though it was used to refer to a tax on meat or slaughtering, the word ''korobka'' (Russian: коробка) actually means "box" in Russian. The tax came to be called that because Jews paying had to deposit a coin in a box at the kosher slaughterer.<ref name=Diner2001p164>[[Hasia R. Diner|Diner, Hasia R.]] ''Hungering for America: Italian, Irish, and Jewish Foodways in the Age of Migration'', [[Harvard University Press]], 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-674-00605-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zU1WYFWxn74C&pg=PA164 p. 164.]</ref>
According to [[Herman Rosenthal]] and [[Jacob Goodale Lipman]], the tax was "the most burdensome and annoying of the special taxes imposed upon the Jews of Russia by the government".<ref name="ji">[[Herman Rosenthal|Rosenthal, Herman]]; [[Jacob Goodale Lipman|Lipman, J.G.]] [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=394&letter=B "Basket-Tax"], ''[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]''.</ref><ref name="Belovinskiĭ2003p357">Leonid Vasilʹevich Belovinskiĭ. ''Энциклопедический словарь российской жизни и истории: XVIII-начало XX в'', Olma Media Group, 2003, {{ISBN|978-5-224-04008-7}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=4W5sUATx57MC&pg=PA357 p. 357.]</ref><ref>[[Simon Dubnow|Dubnow, Simon]]; [[Israel Friedlander|Friedlaender, Israel]]. ''History of the Jews in Russia and Poland'', Avotaynu Inc, 2000 {{ISBN|978-1-886223-11-0}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vL60sEf7OPoC&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227 p. 227.]</ref> The burden of taxes, and the ''korobka'' in particular, was one of the factors which drove many Jews to abandon the towns and settle in villages or on noblemen estates.<ref>Encyclopaedia Judaica (1971): History, vol. 8, 734</ref>
==In Galicia== Between 1777 and 1784, the Jews of [[Horodenka]], a region on the southeast corner of [[Galicia (eastern Europe)|Galicia]], paid a number of special taxes, including the "protection and [[tolerance tax]]", and the "property and occupation tax". In 1784, the property and occupation tax was replaced with the kosher meat tax.<ref>Gelber, N. M. ''The History of the Jews of Horodenka'', p. 86.</ref>
==In Moldavia== In 1741, Moldavian prince [[Grigore II Ghica|Grigore Ghica]] confirmed the obligation of each Jew to pay the crupca, an indirect tax on kosher meat similar to the Russian ''korobka''.<ref>[http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/printarticle.aspx?id=925 Iaşi, by Lucian-Zeev Herşcovici ]</ref>
== In Altona and Hamburg == During the period 1641–1842, the [[Jews]] of [[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]] (then a town close to Hamburg) paid specifically Jewish taxes as well as the same taxes as other residents of Altona. The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents.
In 1640 the Danish King [[Christian IV]] acquired part of the [[Holstein-Pinneberg|County of Pinneberg]] including Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 25–26</ref> Altona was subsequently granted the rights and status of a town on 23 August 1664.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 53–54</ref>
=== Jews in Hamburg ===
The community was founded principally by Portuguese merchants and was known as the [[Portuguese Jewish community in Hamburg|Portuguese-Jewish Community]], although many of its members were of Spanish-Jewish descent.
These [[Sephardic Jews]], who initially pretended to be persecuted [[Catholic]]s, first came to [[Hamburg]] at the end of the 16th century. They were mostly Portuguese- or Spanish-speaking merchants. In 1621, when the armistice between [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] came to an end, many of the Portuguese Jews moved to Hamburg. They were made welcome, even after the actual situation had become clear; however they were not permitted to establish a cemetery within the city walls. Thanks to the linguistic skills of the Sephardim and their contacts among their co-religionaries they controlled a large sector of the German market in provisions. The Sephardim differed culturally and socially from the Jews who came to Altona, and subsequently also to Hamburg, from the east. These were [[Yiddish Language]] speaking [[Ashkenazim]]. The permanent settlement of the Ashkenazim was opposed by both the [[Senate of Hamburg]] (town council) and the citizens, supported by the Sephardim, who did not wish to see the establishment of a second community in Hamburg. As servants, referred to as tudescos, the Ashkenazi Jews were, de facto, under the protection of the Sephardic Jews.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 91–94</ref>
=== Jews in Altona ===
On 1 August 1641 the Danish king had formally granted the Ashkenazi Jews the privilege of having in Altona, as hitherto, a cemetery and a synagogue, thus providing the basis for the existence of a Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 111</ref> Subsequently, the Danish kings promised the Jews personal security, the freedom to practice trade and religious liberties. Some of the Jews living in Hamburg therefore tried to secure the legal protection of the Danish crown in case of any attempt to expel them. In Altona the conditions of residence were favorable, in Hamburg the conditions for trading. These were the reasons for the genesis of the Altona community of Ashkenazi Jews from Hamburg and Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 91</ref> Thanks to immigration from the east, Altona became a center of research and scholarship in Jewish teaching, attracting hundreds of students. The officially recognized [[Beth din|Jewish court of justice]] had a reputation as one of the most distinguished in the whole Jewish world.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 243–244</ref> The Jews did not acquire these privileges freely, but in return for the payment of taxes.
=== Levies on Jews ===
From 1584 to 1639, as in the Middle Ages, the Jews of Altona paid taxes specific to the Jews, but no further taxes. Each Jewish family was required to pay 6 [[rixdollar|Reichstaler]] per year. Under Danish rule this changed: the Jews continued to pay the specifically Jewish taxes plus the same taxes as all other residents.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135</ref> From 1641 every Jewish family was required to pay 5 Reichstaler in Jewish taxes; in the year when Altona became a town the contribution rose to 6 Reichstaler.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135, pp. 180–181</ref> With the ordinance of 1641 the Danish king had permitted the Jews [[shechita]]. This privilege too was not cost-free. For the years 1667–1669 we have records of taxes paid by Jewish butchers. According to these the rates were 1 Mark and 8 Schillinge for an ox, 4 Schillinge for a calf and 2 Schillinge for a lamb. These taxes were twice as high as those paid by Christian butchers.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 153, pp. 168–169</ref> From 1681 Individual taxes on the Jews (6 Reichstaler plus the payments made by the Jewish butchers), were replaced by lump-sum payments by the Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 156</ref>
From the year 1712 onwards it is possible to calculate the amount of the lump-sum payments made by the Jews. During the period 1712–1818 this amounted to 6 Reichstaler for each Jewish family; 6 Reichstaler was the level that had already been set in 1584. Assuming that a Jewish family consisted of approximately 6 persons, 6 Reichstaler corresponded to 1 Reichstaler for each individual Jew. On top of this 1 Reichstaler, also paid by the other residents, had to be paid.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 265-266. Meaningful conversion of the face-value can be made for this period since, unlike the paper money of Copenhagen, the silver currency of Altona was stable, p. 50</ref> The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents. The influence of this on business practice constituted an obstacle to the granting of civil rights. In the year 1818 the Jewish Elders declared to the community of Altona that they could not, ’’on the one hand, levy specifically Jewish taxes on the members of their community and, on the other hand, encourage our co-religionaries, especially the younger ones, to pursue useful activity. In short: so to improve our condition that we might not seem unworthy to acquire civil rights. The extension – against our wishes - of the taxes on the Jews would be incompatible with the granting of civil rights.’’<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 239</ref> This marks the beginning of the struggle of the Jewish community for emancipation. The Jewish community secured the abolition of taxes on the Jews in the year 1842.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 199</ref>

{{Other uses|Veritas (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox political party |colorcode = {{Veritas (political party)/meta/color}} |leader = |foundation = February 2005 |ideology = [[Right-wing populism]]
[[Euroscepticism]] |headquarters = [[London]], [[England]] |international = |country = the United Kingdom |name = Veritas |logo = [[File:Veritas logo.gif|party logo]] |dissolution = June 2015 |split = [[UK Independence Party]] |merged = [[English Democrats]] |position =[[Right-wing]] |national = |european = |europarl = |colours = [[Purple]] }} '''Veritas''' ([[Latin]]: truth) was a [[list of political parties in the United Kingdom|political party in the United Kingdom]], formed in February 2005 by [[Robert Kilroy-Silk]] following a split from the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP). Kilroy-Silk served as party leader from formation, through the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 General Election]], until his resignation in July that year. He was succeeded by Patrick Eston, who resigned the leadership on 15 June 2008 citing frustrations of his efforts to reform the party. The party merged into the [[English Democrats]] in June 2015.{{cite web|title=English Democrats and Veritas to Merge|url=http://www.englishdemocrats.org.uk/latest-news/item/439-english-democrats-and-veritas-to-merge.html|publisher=English Democrats|accessdate=7 October 2015|date=14 June 2015}} Veritas had no representation in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]], although it had members serve in the [[European Parliament]] and the [[London Assembly]], elected as UKIP members and defecting upon Veritas' formation. At the time of its merger, the party had not put forward General Election candidates since 2005.{{cite news|last1=Ross|first1=Jamie|title=We Asked 11 Obscure Political Parties If They Should Be In The TV Debates|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamieross/beer-baccy-and-tv-debates#.vxYN6ZVgv|accessdate=29 July 2015|work=BuzzFeed News|date=20 January 2015}} ==Formation== Robert Kilroy-Silk, a former [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] shadow cabinet member and television presenter, was elected as a UKIP [[Member of the European Parliament]] in the [[European Parliament election, 2004|2004 European Parliament election]] for the [[East Midlands]] region. His ambition to attain the leadership of that party was announced in October 2004, but it proved very unpopular within the party. Instead of risking disciplinary action for continuing this action, Kilroy-Silk resigned the party [[Whip (politics)|whip]], while remaining a full member and asserting his continued challenge. The plan ultimately failed, and Kilroy-Silk finally resigned from the party – as had been long expected – on 20 January 2005. Rumours circulated immediately that Kilroy-Silk was set to form his own party, fuelled by the registration of the domain name "veritasparty.com" a month earlier. An earlier rumour suggested that he had been in negotiations with the [[English Democrats]] to join and lead their party.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/diary/story/0,,1372973,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Politics | first=Marina | last=Hyde | date=14 December 2004 | accessdate=27 May 2010}} ''Veritas'' – [[Latin language|Latin]] for "truth" – was officially founded in a press conference on 2 February, during which Kilroy-Silk proclaimed "unlike the old parties, we shall be honest, open and straight", devoid of the other parties' "lies and spin". There were a number of defections from UKIP to the new party. They included UKIP London Assembly member [[Damian Hockney]], who became deputy leader.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4227921.stm | work=BBC News | title=Kilroy launches 'Veritas' party | date=2 February 2005 | accessdate=27 May 2010}} At the time of formation, its primary policy was opposition to [[immigration to the United Kingdom]]. It was perceived to be more specific than UKIP's general [[euroscepticism]], and almost to the point of Veritas being labelled a [[single-issue party]]. Kilroy-Silk also proposed support for the introduction of [[flat tax]] in opposition to the existing system of income tax bands varying with income. Kilroy-Silk's preferred figure was 22%, the "basic rate" band in which most UK citizens fell at the time. The party was immediately lambasted as nothing more than a vanity vehicle for Kilroy-Silk, and was nicknamed "Vanitas" by former allies.Burkeman, O., [https://www.theguardian.com/guardianpolitics/story/0,,1404364,00.html Kilroy was there], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 3 February 2005. Retrieved 11 October 2007. ==2005 election== The first test of Veritas' ambitions was the general election on 5 May 2005 where it had hoped to overtake UKIP as the primary party opposing the [[European Union]]. Although ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper had suggested that Veritas hoped to run candidates in every constituency in [[Great Britain]], the party ended up fielding 65 candidates in England and Wales, polling 40,481 votes, an average of 623 (1.5%). Kilroy-Silk contested the constituency of [[Erewash (UK Parliament constituency)|Erewash]] in [[Derbyshire]]. He came fourth with 2,957 votes (5.8%); [[Liz Blackman]] was elected for Labour with 22,472. No Veritas candidates were elected; Kilroy-Silk was the only one to save his deposit. In the subsequent [[Cheadle by-election, 2005|Cheadle by-election]] on 14 July 2005 Les Leggett of Veritas polled 218 votes (0.6%). ==Aftermath of 2005 general election== In the wake of the poor showing in the general election, it was reported that there were many resignations from the party. Some discontented party members came to oppose Kilroy-Silk and formed the Veritas Members Association (VMA). One of its founders, Ken Wharton, challenged Kilroy-Silk for the leadership on 12 July 2005, during the Cheadle by-election campaign but his challenge faltered due to ill health.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4675795.stm | work=BBC News | title=Kilroy faces leadership challenge | date=12 July 2005 | accessdate=27 May 2010}} Kilroy-Silk resigned as party leader on 29 July. In a press statement he said "It was clear from the general election result – and more recently that of the Cheadle by-election – that the electors are content with the old parties and that it would be virtually impossible for a new party to make a significant impact given the nature of our electoral system. We tried and failed".{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4728941.stm | work=BBC News | title=Kilroy quits as leader of Veritas | date=29 July 2005 | accessdate=27 May 2010}} Further resignations included that of his chief-of-staff David Soutter and deputy leader Damian Hockney. Hockney and London Assembly Veritas representative [[Peter Hulme-Cross]] (who, like Hockney, had defected from UKIP) subsequently formed the [[One London]] party. A leadership election was held in September 2005. Acting leader Patrick Eston defeated Foreign Affairs Spokesperson Colin Brown, and former boxer [[Winston McKenzie]] on a 22% turnout. This, combined with a poor turnout at the party's first Annual General Meeting, is believed to have brought about the subsequent resignation of Brown and the founders of the VMA. Eston appointed a new party chairman, Alan Ainscow, who resigned from that post and the party in November. As defections and resignations continued, a number of members and former members from Veritas and UKIP, including [[Anthony Bennett (English politician)|Anthony Bennett]] and Ken Wharton, formed a new party, the [[Popular Alliance (UK)|Popular Alliance]] in March 2006. Eston appointed a deputy, Howard Martin, who also is the main Veritas Party spokesperson, and seemed determined to continue with the party, despite the depletion of the Veritas membership. ==2005–15== In the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2006|2006 local elections]], Veritas stood four candidates: two each in [[Kingston-upon-Hull]] and [[Bolton]]. They polled an average of 98 votes each (3.5% of the total). In the 2007 elections, Veritas stood three candidates: two in English council elections and one – Iain James Sheldon in the [[Mid and West Wales (National Assembly for Wales electoral region)|Mid and West Wales]] Region for the Welsh Assembly, who received 502 votes (0.2% of the total). In the summer of 2007, Patrick Eston contacted the leadership of other parties with similar political positions with a view to organising a meeting to discuss co-operation. While all parties were being contacted a later meeting was being arranged for September between Eston and the leaders of the [[Freedom Party (United Kingdom)|Freedom Party]] and [[United Kingdom Popular Democrats]] who had shown interest.[http://www.veritasparty.com/news.html Proposed meeting on 31 August] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629182440/http://www.veritasparty.com/news.html |date=29 June 2007 }} On 15 June 2008 Patrick Eston announced that he could not take the Veritas Party in the direction he wanted and so would be resigning the party leadership. In a resignation letter to the party membership he said: :"I have come to the reluctant conclusion that the only way a new political party can move forward is for one person to have complete control and take all the decisions. However, I believe that members must have a say on whether that person stays as leader on a yearly basis. A sort of benevolent dictator that members can remove yearly if they so wish." Therese Muchewicz, Party Secretary, served as Acting Leader until leadership elections in October 2008. She was subsequently elected as the new Party Leader. The party put forward no candidates in the 2010 or 2015 UK General Elections It was subsequently announced that Veritas would merge into the English Democrats. ==See also== * [[Alliance for Democracy (UK)]] * [[English Democrats]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Veritas (Political Party)}} [[Category:Veritas (political party)| ]] [[Category:2005 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2015 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 2015]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2005]] [[Category:Eurosceptic parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political schisms]] [[Category:UK Independence Party breakaway groups]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in England]] [[Category:English Democrats]]

{{Use British English|date=July 2015}} [[File:Christmas in Birmingham - Winterval poster 1998.jpg|alt="Poster with the headline 'Christmas in Birmingham', then a picture if a mother and children, with the words 'Come for the shopping, stay for the day'. Below that, in smaller type, the Birmingham City Council and Winterval 1998 logos."|thumb|right|1998 'Christmas in Birmingham' poster, with the Winterval logo in smaller type than the word 'Christmas']]
'''Winterval''' was a season of public events in [[Birmingham]], [[England]], organised by [[Birmingham City Council]] in each of two consecutive [[winter]]s: first from 20 November to 31 December 1997,<ref name="bcc1997"> {{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971210073015/http://birmingham.gov.uk/winterval/index.html |url=http://birmingham.gov.uk/winterval/index.html |archivedate=10 December 1997 |accessdate=21 October 2009 |date=19 November 1997 |title=Winterval 1997 |publisher=Birmingham City Council }}</ref> and then again from mid-October 1998 to mid-January 1999. The intention was to encourage people into the newly rejuvenated city centre,<ref name="guar2006"> {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/dec/08/religion.communities |title=The phoney war on Christmas |first=Oliver |last=Burkeman |work=The Guardian |date=8 December 2006 |location=London}} </ref> with [[secular]] and [[religion|religious]] events marking religious and other occasions during the relevant period. The name "Winterval" has since become used in the UK as shorthand for what are presented as attempts to "[[Rebranding|rebrand]]" Christmas so as not to exclude non-[[Christian]]s.
== 1997 == The name "Winterval" was a [[portmanteau]] of ''[[winter]]'' and ''[[festival]]'', coined by the Council's Head of Events, Mike Chubb.<ref name="pigsonthewing">{{cite web|url=http://pigsonthewing.org.uk/winterval-the-truth/ |title=Winterval – the truth |publisher=Pigsonthewing.org.uk |date=2008-10-30 |accessdate=2011-11-08}}</ref> In October 2008 he explained:<ref name="pigsonthewing"/>
{{quote|Quite simply, as head of events at that time, we needed a vehicle which could cover the marketing of a whole season of events... [[Diwali]] (the Festival of Lights), Christmas Lights switch-on, [[BBC]] [[Children in Need]], [[Aston Hall]] by Candlelight, [[Chinese New Year]], [[New Year's Eve]], etc. Also, a season that included theatre shows, an open-air [[ice-rink]], the Frankfurt Open-air Christmas Market and the Christmas seasonal retail offer. Christmas—called Christmas!—and its celebration lay at the heart of Winterval.
[[Political correctness]] was never the reasoning behind Winterval, but yes, it was intended to be inclusive—which is no bad thing to my mind—and a brand to which other initiatives could be developed as part of the Winterval offer, in order to sell the city at a time when all cities are competing against each other for the seasonal trade.}}
The programme of events in 1997 included theatre and arts events; marking of [[Diwali]]; candlelit tours of [[Aston Hall]]; an outdoor [[ice rink]]; a German-style [[Christmas market]]; [[Christmas lights (holiday decoration)|Christmas lights]] in the streets; and a [[New Year's Eve]] Party.<ref name="bcc1997"/> The front cover of the promotional brochure used the word "Christmas" three times<ref name="bcc1997"/> and featured a photograph of the City's official [[Christmas tree]].<ref name="bcc1997"/> Each of its six pages featured the word "Christmas" in text or images.<ref name="bcc1997"/>
== 1998 ==
The extended Winterval the following year included: [[Hallowe'en]]; [[Guy Fawkes Night]]; [[Diwali]]; [[Ramadan]] and [[Eid ul-Fitr|Eid]]; [[Hanukkah]]; [[Advent]], [[Christmas]], and [[Boxing Day]]; [[New Year's Eve]]; and [[Chinese New Year]].
Posters were displayed, advertising Christmas events, with the word "Christmas" in large type, and the "Winterval 98" logo only as a footnote.<ref name="Pickles">{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.net/news/politics-news/2010/11/30/local-government-secretary-eric-pickles-attacks-1998-s-winterval-65233-27738640/|title=Local Government secretary Eric Pickles attacks 1998's Winterval|last=Walker|first=Jonathan|date=2010-11-30|publisher=[[Birmingham Post]]|accessdate=28 September 2011}}</ref>
[[Church of England]] leaders in Birmingham criticised the 1998 "Winterval" concept. [[Mark Santer]], then [[Bishop of Birmingham]], said in a message to his parishes that he "laughed out loud" when he learned of the concept of Winterval, which he considered to be "a way of not talking about Christmas" and "a well-meaning attempt not to offend". He wondered whether Christianity had been censored.<ref name="bbc1998">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/210672.stm |title=UK | Winterval gets frosty reception |publisher=BBC News |date=1998-11-09 |accessdate=2011-11-08}}</ref> The [[Archdeacon]] of [[Aston]] called it "a totally unnecessary example of political correctness to avoid sensitivities people simply do not have".<ref name="bbc1998"/> The council responded that "Christmas is the very heart of Winterval", saying that Christmas-themed events were prominent among those included in Winterval, and that Christmas-related words and symbols were prominent in its publicity material.<ref name="bbc1998"/> While the Winterval season was longer than the Christmas season, Christmas was the focus of the relevant portion of Winterval, and a statement from Birmingham Council explained:<ref name="guar2006"/>
{{quote|...there was a banner saying Merry Christmas across the front of the council house, Christmas lights, Christmas trees in the main civil squares, regular carol-singing sessions by school choirs, and the Lord Mayor sent a Christmas card with a traditional Christmas scene wishing everyone a Merry Christmas.}}
Neighbouring [[Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council|Solihull council]] invited Birmingham residents desiring a traditional Christmas to go there instead.<ref name="guar2006"/>
== Legacy == Birmingham City Council did not use the name "Winterval" after the 1998–9 season,<ref name="guar2006"/> but it persists as shorthand for any secular replacement for Christmas, used both by supporters<ref> {{cite press release |url=http://www.churchinwales.org.uk/press/display_press_release.php?prid=4542 |publisher=[[The Church in Wales]] |title=Christmas Message: Message of the nativity excludes no-one |quote=Virulent attacks on religion by atheists, he <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Barry Morgan]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> says, are undermining Christian society, leading to new rules such as Christmas being renamed as “Winterval” and Christians being forbidden to wear crosses at work. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316070109/http://www.churchinwales.org.uk/press/display_press_release.php?prid=4542 |archivedate=16 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }} </ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-419740/Campaign-real-Christmas-Religious-leaders-unite-political-correctness.html |title=Campaign for a real Christmas: Religious leaders unite against political correctness |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/632P1zVAc?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-419740/Campaign-real-Christmas-Religious-leaders-unite-political-correctness.html |archivedate=8 November 2011 |date=2006-12-01 |accessdate=2011-11-08 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and opponents<ref>{{cite news|first1=Richard|last1=Ford|first2=Anushka|last2=Asthana |author-link2=Anushka Asthana|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,1072-2497599,00.html |title=The Times | UK News, World News and Opinion |publisher=Timesonline.co.uk |date=2009-06-25 |accessdate=2011-11-08 |location=London}}</ref> of the traditional Christmas; it is also cited as a cautionary tale or urban legend by those who regard allegations of the existence of a "[[war on Christmas]]" as overblown.<ref name="guar2006"/>
On 8 November 2011 the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' issued a correction<ref name="DM-apology">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/article-2058830/Clarifications-corrections.html |title=Clarifications and corrections |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/632PVQm8Q?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/article-2058830/Clarifications-corrections.html |archivedate=8 November 2011 |date=8 November 2011 |accessdate=2011-11-08 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Baxter">{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/steven-baxter/2011/11/christmas-mail-winterval|title=On Winterval and the Mail|last=Baxter|first=Steven|date=2011-11-08|work=[[New Statesman]]|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> after using the term 'Winterval' in an opinion piece by [[Melanie Phillips]], which it ran on 26 September 2011,<ref name="Phiips">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-2041765/BBC-BC-AD-debate-Our-language-hijacked-Left.html|title=BBC BC/AD debate: Our language is being hijacked by the Left|last=Philips|first=Melanie|date=2011-09-25|work=[[Mail Online]]|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=8 November 2011|location=London}} - note: though dated 25 September on-line, the article ran in the print edition dated 26 September</ref> stating:
{{quote|Winterval was the collective name for a season of public events, both religious and secular, which took place in Birmingham in 1997 and 1998. We are happy to make clear that Winterval did not rename or replace Christmas.|source=Daily Mail<ref name="DM-apology" />}}
The "Winterval" trope was also debunked by [[Stephen Fry]], in a 2007 episode of the quiz-show ''[[QI]]''.<ref name= "">{{Cite episode |title=Empire |series=QI |serieslink=QI |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRlZvn-KiH4 |accessdate=7 October 2017 |network= [[BBC Television]] |date= 7 December 2007 |season=E |number=12 |transcript= |transcripturl= }}</ref>
The lawyer and law correspondent [[David Allen Green]], and the campaigner [[Inayat Bunglawala]] both included Winterval as an example in evidence to the [[Leveson Inquiry]] into the culture, practices and ethics of the British press.<ref name="Allen Green">{{cite web |last1=Allen Green |first1=David |authorlink1=David Allen Green |title=Witness Statement of David Allen Green |url=http://www.levesoninquiry.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Witness-Statement-of-David-Allen-Green.pdf |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20140122175531/http://www.levesoninquiry.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Witness-Statement-of-David-Allen-Green.pdf|archivedate=22 January 2014 |page=6}}</ref><ref name="Bowater">{{cite news|last1=Bowater|first1=Donna|title=Leveson Inquiry: as it happened January 24|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/leveson-inquiry/9037670/Leveson-Inquiry-as-it-happened-January-24.html|accessdate=7 October 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=2012}}</ref> Green wrote:<ref name="Allen Green" />
{{Quote|Within the "blogosphere" here are a number of highly regarded bloggers who specialise in exposing poor quality or misleading journalism... What happens is that a selected news story or column is subjected to scrutiny ("fact-checked") and the apparent basis for the story or column questioned. One excellent example of this is the destruction by bloggers of the Tabloid staple of "Winterval"...}}
